availability.p: The British Academic Spoken English (BASE) corpus was developed at the Universities of Warwick and Reading, under the directorship of Hilary Nesi (Centre for English Language Teacher Education, Warwick) and Paul Thompson (Department of Applied Linguistics, Reading), with funding from BALEAP, EURALEX, the British Academy and the Arts and Humanities Research Board. The original recordings are held at the Universities of Warwick and Reading, and at the Oxford Text Archive and may be consulted by bona fide researchers upon written application to any of the holding bodies. The BASE corpus is freely available to researchers who agree to the following conditions:
1. The recordings and transcriptions should not be modified in any way
2. The recordings and transcriptions should be used for research purposes only; they should not be reproduced in teaching materials

3. The recordings and transcriptions should not be reproduced in full for a wider audience/readership, although researchers are free to quote short passages of text (up to 200 running words from any given speech event)
4. The corpus developers should be informed of all presentations or publications arising from analysis of the corpus

Researchers should acknowledge their use of the corpus using the following form of words: The recordings and transcriptions used in this study come from the British Academic Spoken English (BASE) corpus, which was developed at the Universities of Warwick and Reading under the directorship of Hilary Nesi (Warwick) and Paul Thompson (Reading). Corpus development was assisted by funding from the Universities of Warwick and Reading, BALEAP, EURALEX, the British Academy and the Arts and Humanities Research Board.

body.u: well good afternoon everybody # today's lecture's topic is tension structures as you can see # this term encompasses all kinds of # three-dimensional structural forms and two-dimensional structural forms # ranging from suspension bridges cable nets cable trusses and fabric fabric membranes now all these terms will become clearer as we go through the lecture we've got plenty of illustrative examples to show you the lecture falls into several parts initially is going to in introduce # the basic principles behind the structural actions in tension structures i will then move on to discussing fabric membranes and then we conclude the lecture or first part of the lecture # with # pneumatic membrane structures # in the second part of the lecture we're going to show you a video on tension structures which will reinforce some of the concepts ideas presented in the first part of the lecture and then finally we're going to move on to a workshop where we we're going to be experimenting with # tensegrities and what else # reciprocal frames
# and so on so it's going to be an action packed afternoon okay i hope you're going to enjoy it now over to

right well as # has said i'm going to introduce some of the basic principles # of tensile structures and one of the really basic principles is the fact that they are tensile structures and you can demonstrate their efficiency by something as simple as a strip of paper which # will carry quite a reasonable load in tension but you try and invert this structure so that it's carrying this load in compression turn it the other way up and of course it won't even support its own weight so that's the first lesson to learn that tensile structures are highly efficient because they they don't buckle # i'm sure you all know about buckling behaviour of structures and the majority of materials are actually reasonably strong in tension therefore # you can use most materials as # for tension structures # the second thing we're going to look at is the # behaviour of horizontal tension structures and # the simplest form of that is just a structure hanging under its own weight and here i've got a a chain # which is hanging under its own weight and as you can see it forms a curve and this curve where it's # just acting under its own # self-weight is known as a catenary curve the load is not quite uniform along the structure as a a metre of span at the end is # contains a greater length of cable than # a metre in the middle if we then put some load on the structure you see that # in fact it's now changed shape and # a point load in the centre forms approximately a V-shape structure if we then put # an additional load on the structure we see that it's changed shape again and # forming a trapezoidal shape and # in the handout you can see that # i've given you the different shapes that # a cable actually takes up # depending on the loading # the top there we have # the catenary under self-weight of the cable and as i said # the weight of the cable actually at the ends is greater per metre of span than it is in the middle here # if you take a a uniformly distributed load on the the cable or chain then it takes up a parabolic form # if you have a load that's zero in the centre and maximum at the ends then you get an n an elliptical # form of the cable or chain # point load gives you a triangle and that varies depending on the position of the load # trapezoidal where you have two loads and # the more loads you add you get # a polygonal sh shape so that's # the second leshon lesson to learn about # this type of structure they they are # they change shape as according to the load as the load changes the shape of the structure changes and these are known as funicular structures one thing that we we need to look at # for tension structures they can't just act on their own in tension they have to be restrained in some way and # we can look at various # retr restraining systems and again you've got these in the handout # the most obvious one the most commonly used one is to have c cables supported on some mast structures and then to tie this structure back # to a foundation in the ground with # another tension element so you have a continuous cable round # this acts is acting in compression the rest is in tension and then you need some form of of anchorage at the bottom an alternative way of # restraining this type of structure is to # have some form of buttressing system # where you have inclined supports and # this diagram shows a massive buttressing system where the self-weight of the buttress is causing an overturning moment and that tensions up the cable maintains it in position so the cable's pulling here creating a moment in this direction and the supporting structure the eccentric self-weight creates a moment in the other direction and the third type of system is to actually have a some closed ring round your tension structure so in this case here we've got # a series of cables simply sp spanning # a space here and # these connect to a a rigid beam round the outside # # which would be in bending and then the force from this side is carried in compression across to the other side so you actually form a a closed circuit so that's # three ways of retaining the structure # these are all lightweight structures and therefore # a major problem is to # restrain the structure when you have wind loading # as you know or i hope you know by now # on structures that are fairly flat # you tend to get # suction wind forces and therefore # although the dead loads of the structure are acting downwards under gravity the wind loads are trying to lift the structure up and a cable is very resistant when the loads are down but it doesn't have much resistance when you're trying to resist suction forces the structure will deform a lot so # there are various ways of # restraining # the wind uplift forces the obvious one is to increase the self-weight of the structure over the span so you in increase the dead weight # which to me is completely opposed to the idea of having a tension lightweight structure if you then put a lot of load on it to to stop it from moving about in the wind so although that works and is used sometimes it's to me not the ideal solution another way of restraining which is slightly better is to actually put some # inverted arch or shell structure # around the cable and that again is a relatively heavyweight structure and # to me is not a particularly good solution although it's lighter than the first one where you're just using dead load you are are actually using a a structure here to to resist the uplift forces # the third way is # to actually have an opposing cable so you have a hanging cable and then you have # another cable which is curved in the opposite direction and between those in this case you have some struts # there are various ways you can do this you could actually have a cable which runs on another profile down here and have struts in the middle and ties at the ends so there are various combinations or permutations of this but this is forming what's known as a cable truss system and there you are actually having a lightweight # structure this is in one plane but # also you have problems you need to restrain the structure in the other direction so a fourth solution which # is probably # the best is to actually have some transverse cables so you've got one set of cables hanging in one direction then in the other direction these cables that ran in the planar truss across the top here are running across your structure so you have a system in one direction hanging and in the opposite direction these cables are inverted and they are actually prestressed against each other so that's the the various sort of stabilizing systems to resist wind uplift right so # that's the sort of theory and # now i'll go on and show you some slides # which demonstrate these types of structures

# starting with a an early form of tension structure # a sailing sailing boat of course demonstrates # two or three different types of tension structure the stays # the mast and # the membranes the sails very simple membrane structures and these would use # cellulose fibre e elements # as the tension elements of course # suspension bridges were also made using # ropes and # rattan binds and so on # to make simple tension # suspension bridges but the the earliest long span bridges were made using wrought iron and # this is the Menai Suspension Bridge across to the Island of Anglesey in Wales # designed by Thomas Telford # finished in eighteen-twenty-six using wrought iron which was sort of the new strong tensile material and # it would actually work to the limit of the of the material eighty-eight # newtons per square millimetre as the tensile strength and this is hanging in a sort of somewhere between the parabolic and # catenary curve # with # more modern materials high strength steel once steel was developed in the eighteen-fifties then # various processes produced # high strength steel wires and Roebling the # North American engineer # made some very elegant # suspension bridges including one over Niagara Falls this is Brooklyn Bridge in # New York and you can see the suspension cables and also some cable stays # as # modern materials and design methods have improved we can see now this is the Severn Bridge which is one of the longest spans in the world although the Japanese have now got # a bridge which is almost two kilometres long # you can see the the size of the tension elements have gone down # over the years as material strengths have improved as an example of the of the buttress system this is # Dulles Airport in Washington where # you can see these inclined columns are actually sort of tilted away from the roof span which is cables running between these columns and then to stabilize it it does actually use the inverted shell type structure so you have a system of cables enclosed by # reinforced concrete # one of the earliest # enclosed ring type systems was the Raleigh arena where you have a system of cables running in this direction and another system of cables running in a in the other dir opposing direction and that is actually enclosed within this ring of two inclined arches which are self-stressing because the weight of the arch is trying to pull the structure this is tending to fall down in this direction tensioning the # the cables crossing the str across the span taking the idea of the cable truss into # three dimensions # the simplest a simple structure is # the bicycle wheel type structure where you have a n a node in the centre where all the cable trusses meet and you have a ring beam which is in compression and this is exactly the same as a bicycle wheel # the bike that you ride # you have a similar sort of system a compression ring round the outside and the hub in the middle and you are actually riding on tension when you ride a bicycle # this is an example in Tunisia of # one of these bicycle wheel type roofs # other tension type structures you can have # straight # cable stays and these are used for bridges and for buildings this is the Inmos factory in # south Wales and you can see this is almost like an inverted tree type structure with all of these in direct tension and then the compression structure supporting that in the centre or the Renault parts distribution factory in Swindon # architect # Norman Foster and # quite well known among in the architectural world for the bright yellow structure the high-tech s style # this again is cable-stayed in three dimensions the the sort of cable trusses work across and in three directions # the Fleetguard f # Factory in Quimper in # France # a Richard Rogers # project # this again is # cable-stayed and has cables that run in # hanging and in the inverted direction to resist wind forces on the roof and # this slide also shows that you need some restraining s system for horizontal wind forces in this type of structure another form of # three-dimensional # tensile structure is the cable dome and this shows the principle of # the cable dome developed by # David Geiger and used for some of the Olympic # structures in Seoul and # here shows the cross section the structure's originally hanging and then you tension up these cables on the outside that lifts up this ring of struts # this is in three dimensions # and then you taesio tension up the next cable lifts up this ring of struts and so on until you end up with a dome shape # in three dimensions this # i think i've showed you before in one of the earlier lectures the # Atlanta sor Georgia Dome in Atlanta which # was used for the # last Olympic Games and # here a similar sort of cable cable dome was used and this is the inside you can see the the struts and the inclined cables and the rings of cables

introduced the general principles # of tension structures but concentrating on non-fabric # tension structures what i'll be talking about are fabric membranes tension membranes and by fabric i understand both the material membranes and cable nets as well # if i can have the first slide now # in general fabric fabric membranes offer limitless possibilities to create large unobstructive # unobstructed areas to provide shelter from rain snow wind # here we see # a beach residence a beach palace in Saudi Arabia built in # i think nineteen-ninety the and designed by a German firm Sonderkonstruktionen und Leichtbau # for short S-L # if you look at the view inside # you can see lovely curvatures developing but also what we see here are the lines of the cutting pattern this is something that i will # discuss later 'cause it's one thing to derive a shape of the membrane another one is to actually build it out of strips of fabric as you can see here # another example it's a convertible roof for an open-air thea air theatre in # Luxembourg # it's a hanging fabric structure in unopened state and here you'll see it in open state # again it was designed # by S-L and consultant i think Frei Otto from Stuttgart # that was a a an earlier structure nineteen-eighty-eight these are convertible umbrellas for a mosque in Medina in Saudi Arabia again designed by S-L you see these umbrellas here in a semi-open state # and then in fully open state the fabric used # was woven Teflon # it's the most expensive fabric you can have # and it was coated # with tetrafluoride coating to protect it from # sun degradation # the posts are air-conditioned they pro produce air conditioning # during the summer and during winter as well wouldn't it be lovely to have something like that in the middle of over Lady Godiva what a difference it would make but one umbrella costs somewhere around one-million pounds because it's got gold and precious stones there as well # the reason why these structures are seen # in countries such as Saudi Arabia is because of the # the religion there and the belief in purity of form # closer to home # this is from 's town i don't know if you want to be associated with Nottingham but this is Inland Revenue in Nottingham a membrane structure the fabric used there is # P-V-C coated polyester # the structure doesn't look particularly lightweight what creates a an image of of it being # light is that all the steel elements the the the masts and the structure inside # were painted white but there's a lot of steel in the structure and it does not actually look lightweight now here you see some detail # between the fabric panels # and again the the seams # cutting pattern seams which are not very attractive to to the eye construction detail these are often very very important to prevent structure from deterioration you can see the end detail here and another one which shows a a sort of uniform distribution of # stresses along the edge of the the membrane and moving on to # cable nets now # this is an example of a aviary in Munich except it's not really a cable structure # it's a mesh # made of # wires it's a it's a wire mesh stretched over over some metal posts which are actually stabilized by means of # cable stays and you can see # a construction process here # but the problems that these structure present are similar to those that fabric membranes # present for designers that is # finding the shape and finding the cutting pattern for the complete structure now going to a more classical example of membrane structures here we see # Munich Olympic Complex # the stadium which sort of resembles the shape of a caterpillar if if if you think it does resemble a caterpillar the designers # would be delighted because it's supposed to resemble natural structures a swimming pool and a sports' stadium # it isn't really a fabric membrane it's a cable # roof membrane can s perhaps see a better picture of it here # it's a s it's a a grid of cables # overlaid with acrylic panels translu # acrylic cladding there's a better slide of it here as you can see # Munich Olympic Complex marked a departure from # physical modelling of this structure up until then up un until nineteen-seventy-two # tension membranes were designed with help of a physical model you can see a physical model here for the # the Munich # Olympic Stadium and then measurements were taken sort of painstaking # care and then the dimensions of the structure would be scaled up but that of course created errors # what we see here is an earlier structure it's Montreal # it was German # pavilion for the Expo sixty-seven in Montreal it's a cable net and fabric structure # designed by # Frei Otto and his team from the Institute of s of Lightweight Structures in Stuttgart # this structure was totally designed using fabric models and # soap film models you can see another view of the same structure here # w what is of interest are these eye loops here and they are there purely to distribute the stresses because alou around the masts we've got concentration of stresses and this is to do to to dissipate the stresses # this is a construction of the actual net # a physical model with an eye loop which also serves as a window and a soap film model i shall talk about soap film models a little bit more later on because soap films are a means of # deriving the shape deriving the form the way in which this eye loop has been formed was by placing a string on a soap film and then drawing the # the soap film up as far it could go to to derive the shape # this is a a fabric model in fact # the earlier if i go back the earlier structure is a prototype for the Institute of # e Lightweight Structures in Stuttgart which was a part of the # # the complex for Montreal and the structure was actually transported # on the university campus it is now preserved as a historical building if you ever visit University of Stuttgart it really is worth a visit going to look at the structure from outside and inside as well # okay and that's the shape was derived with the help of a soap film model here we've got a fabric model with some instrumentation some load input on it to take some measurements of how it would deflect under loading and a cable net model as well and the cutting pattern model there are various possibilities in which you can cut fabric to get # the required form but this really # is an area of intensive research now i've already touched upon the subject of # modelling # indicating that one can # use fabric models and soap film models to derive sh the shape of tension membranes but of course nowadays what we tend to do is to model these shapes using computer # so here is a computational model of a a fabric membrane and the same structure modelled using a soap film and using fabric okay the problem with # computational modelling is that tension membranes are geometrical non-linear structures they # deflect a lot under given loading so compared to the traditional sort of rigid s # structural forms in which the displacement of the structure corresponds to the amount of loading # this relationship is actually # not valid for tension structures we cannot describe # the behaviour # by this equation stiffness matrix multiplied by displacement equals load and from from that relationship ship therefore we can d calculate displacements and we solve the structure for loads and for displacements if we did that with a tension membrane what we would what we would find we calculate the displacements we feed those displacements back to the original equation and we find we get a different right-hand side not equal to the load applied load P but something P with a tilde and then what we have to do then is to calculate the difference be between P and P-delta P P-tilde to get an increment in displacement and we have to keep accumulating this i increments and substituting to this equation until we actually satisfy this equation so it's the modelling is done in an iterative process and on your handout there is a full explanation of with what is actually going on as far as # mathematical modelling or computational modelling is concerned to show you # a stages of numerical modelling i've got a little example # to show you next # if we were to model a membrane such as you see here # on plan # what we would do we would # if we've got a powerful computer program as a first guess we would say we want to stretch a membrane between these boundaries and it has to reach this this boundary circle here so initially we we say it's flat except for the last roof elements and if we iterate # and start refining the shape until we get an equilibrium then we get # the actual this is a plan view of the shape we s we get a elements which are distorting on on plan kind of spider spider's web initially if i look back you see these lines were straight what we end up is something like that and the final structure looks like that so that creates problems keeping the line the lines of the # # of the elements straight because ideally we should we would like to use those form as cutting pattern lines as seam lines but it is not always # possible

there is no denying that lightweight tension membranes are very popular structures particularly amongst architects because they can convey a very dramatic expression you can create very exciting shapes # utilizing fabric in tension but also # they have a great potential for carrying loads efficiently this brings us to the point of what constitutes an efficient structure and to follow a quotation from i forget who the author of this book is one of the # recently published book on # structural architecture or structural art # the message that comes across is this for an efficient structure use tension rather than compression and either in preference to bending ironically what we teach you here is nothing but bending bending bending bending of beams bending of columns bending of slats okay so this course has been put on to # take you away from this a little bit now we need to consider the difference the basic differences between tension membranes and conventional structures so if we were to summarize the main features of tension membranes the first point that has to be made is that the shape of a tension membrane has to be found # there is no mathematical function that will describe the surface this is the problem so you have to resolve into some kind of form finding before you start # the structure can increase its stresses under say wind loading given even tenfold so initial surface tensions have to be low the structure undergoes very large displacements which leads to geometrical non-linearity which has to be modelled in modelled on computer # as an iterative process of satisfying proven equations and finally because the the design process is so complex the analysis form # the analysis part forms a very significant cost # part of the whole cost of the of the design unlike for conventional structures when # the designer's fees are are very low compared to all the other # costs and these costs are attributed mainly to the fact that we have a three stage design procedure which involves form finding patterning and static analysis now i only touched upon form finding which means finding a three-dimensional shape under tension patterning is the stage where you try to construct the membrane from finite strips of fabric and in they come about two to three metres wide and then final s finally static analysis we have to see how the shape is going to behave under wind loading # or snow loading and if the deflections are excessive or if flat areas will develop then you go back to form finding refining your form again how do we go about form finding the first stage well we can resort to # resort to construction of physical models or we can use # computational model n models as far as physical models are concerned there is a a variety of them here these these were made by your predecessors as you can see and each one of them # has been arrived as as a result of sort of iterative process of refining the boundaries rethinking the the the the function and so on there are more models that we can show you # later on # as well so that's physical modelling # soap films are a very good # material to use as well except that # in order to take measurements you have to be # using specialist equipment for taking photographs of soap film models # but they certainly can be used to verify your computational modelling

i've put this slide here because very often engineers are unsure what form finding means we're so used to dealing with rigid forms where we dictate the shape we know what the building is going to look like but unfortunately with membrane structures you have to find the shape the structure will adopt its own shape it the shape cannot be dictated by the designer # the only thing that can be dictated are the boundaries of the structure and to a s to a s to some extent you can alter the shape of the surface by differentially prestressing # membrane between the boundaries now if we concentrate just on computer based form finding what what does it mean what does form what can form finding computer based form finding produ produce there are numerous computer programs now developed and in use all over the world and they can do the following they can either find an optimal shape for you i will s de i'll # describe what i mean by optimal shape in a moment they can find a shape which is in static equilibrium but not necessarily an optimum shape or this is the worst case they can find a shape for you which only approximates the state of equilibrium and i've i've come across case cases like that this last case correspond to the situation where # there are certain inherent assumptions in the computer program # which # first of all # don't # allow the computer algorithm to work very well so at the end of the iterative procedure you don't get get a convergence sometimes lack of # experience of the analyst come comes into it # and i've come across comments from # for example Australian engineers who said well we do our analysis we put the wind load on the structure if the program doesn't converge we just forget about it okay # an optimal shape of a tension membrane is a shape such that it usem uses a minimal amount of material # and this can only be achieved if you have a minimum surface area a minimum surface area corresponds to what's known a minimal surface and the only structure that can reproduce minim minimal surfaces are soap film surfaces so soap films are very good analogues for # finding shape of membranes however there's quite a lot of controversy associated with soap soap film analogy and # i think witnessed some exchanges at conferences between me and various other engineers about wer about this # problem because it is claimed that soap films are optimized only for one load case which is its own surface tension but to counteract these the these arguments one can see that the the initial surface tension in a structure this is before you apply snow load and wind load is the only permanent load acting on the structure all the other loads are temporary so it makes sense to optimize for that load load case so really there's no case made # there

if i were to summarize # what is actually going on in the field of # the design of tension membranes i would say that there is still a lot of research needed i've got my research student here who's working with me on # computer modelling of tension membranes but applied to automotive industry # convertible car hoods and the factors that need to be considered are are first of all cost and durability because still despite their attractiveness tension membranes are not # competitive against conventional roofing forms # the design process can take deriving the shape on the computer is not too difficult but cutting patterns yes they create a problem it can take up to two days to to to actually come up with a reasonable cutting pattern and even then the designers are not sure whether they should cut the fabric this way or that way what would give # a optimum use of the material # while at the same time would reproduce # you # the the surf the surface the form found surface because one final point i would like to make is that even if we did reproduce the soap film surface on computer accurately not everybody's capable of doing that but even if we did the second problem is we have to flatten this surface in order to get a cutting pattern and minimal surfaces soap film surfaces are non-developable surfaces so inevitably there will be d errors involved and distortions involved and how you minimize these errors # is a problem and as far as durability's concerned one should avoid at any cost differential prestressing of fabric but unfortunately this is what the designers do these days if the shape doesn't look right # because the boundaries were ill chosen they tend to prestress the fabric in one direction more than in the other to control the shape and the result of that is that the structure with time will creep anyway will try to adopt the minimum energy form anyway so such attempts are are futile # and differential prestressing of fabrics will lead to fatigue of fibres as well those which are stressed more are going to # not not going to last as as long that is all i can say # what i haven't talked about is # pneumatic membranes everyth everything i've said so far relates to surface stressed membranes where they are stressed by means of tension applied to the boundary # but another category of structures # that i use # are so-called pneumatic structures and i think would like to show you a few slides about those they are stressed differently they're not stressed at the boundary they're stressed by air pressure inside them

# yes as 's just said the # membrane structures are do have to be pretensioned in some way and the difference with inflated structures is this pretension is actually applied by # an air pressure within somewhere within the structure so here's an example just to show what you can do with inflated structures # you may just spot there's something like a a hoover motor down here blowing this # dinosaur up so you can see the sort of thing that you can do with # inflated structures # we've all # come across inflated structures # blown up balloons for parties even a simple # bag foil bag you can just blow that up with air pressure but if you have the wrong shape of structure then in fact you get these wrinkles which if you're having a permanent structure you don't really want these these are undesirable # make the structure a bit more flexible the surface of the structure more flexible and of course we # every time we use # road transport # we ride on inflatable structures the tyres of cars and bicycles are load supporting inflated structures # the forms of inflatable structures can be modelled # using soap # soap films and this is # these are a slide of # some of the experiments done by Frei Otto # in the nineteen-sixties # showing how you can combine soap bubble shapes and these could be used potentially for inflated structures right if i can switch to the # overhead now

# # there are various # types of # air inflated structures and i don't have any fancy computer generated pictures # these are freehand sketches # the simplest one is just a single skin structure with # air pressure inside and that's what's known as an air supported structure then the the next type is an air inflated structure where you have a double skin and # generally this requires a higher pressure of air in between the two skins and that that forms an encloses the space then with a double skin in this case the air pressure is inside the structure inside the complete volume in this second case the air pressure is on the inside in between those two walls they're the two basic types of structure then there are variations on that hybrids # you can combine # high pressure tubes inflated tubes and # in this case here evacuate a double skinned membrane in between the high pressure tubes # to form an enclosed space # the basic # air supported volume can be restrained and reinforced by # cables set within the structure so you get this sort of chrysalis type form # quite organic looking structure # an alternative form is to have # very similar to the previous one here is just to have # high pressure tubes and a simple membrane unpressurized in between the two and a final hybrid type form # is to have an air supported structure but then to actually stiffen the walls by having those inflated so in this case it's a # sort of hemispherical structure you've got air pressure inside to maintain it and then these are double skins and # they're inflated with pressure as well # so a combination of # support air support and # air inflation various types of structure right if i could go back to the slides i'll show you a few examples of # those structures this is # and the majority of them are actually yeah inflated structures this is an air inflated structure the German pavilion at the Expo nineteen-ninety-two in Seville where the there were two # steel rings and # a double skin membrane # spanning between those two rings and then that the the space between with two membranes was inflated with air and that formed # this sort of taurus type structure which was then suspended with another tensile structure # from the mast in the centre here and with the stabilizing cables to hold it in position so it does actually demonstrate a couple of # tensile type structures then in the United States # there are various # air supported structures used for large stadiums and # in these the air pressure is actually inside the whole stadium and # to stop it going into a ballooning into a huge roof there are restraining cables # to hold the structure down and minimize the volume that has to be inflated # problems occur with these these type of structures where you can get sort of strange bulges and # with # ice and snow the valleys fill up and you can actually have rupture of the membrane due to overloading # if you the valleys fill with ponds # you might recognize this person in the middle here # this is # an air system of air inflated structures that were # assembled at the University of Nottingham for a conference last year by students from Stuttgart # i think i've shown you just a single slide of this before # these are actually salami skins salami sausage skins # to demonstrate # how you can actually produce # quite large air inflated structures # these were actually ten metres high # this is the basic material and # this is how crude the assembly method was just # tying off the ends of the s sausage tubes # this gives you some idea of the scale of the structures # and the air inflation is sufficient for them to be rigid # self-supporting columns ten metres high # and and to resist # light breezes as lateral loading # this se shows what happens with the tubes when they go into bending # because # as we were saying bending actually is a less efficient way of carrying loading but if you want curved-shaped forms you might actually have some bending in your structure and you might notice how this actually forms # what # i was talking about in one of the earlier lectures natural structures the # structure of # cane # where you have the nodes at # points up the # up a tubular structure and that actually tends to reinforce it and the same happens naturally in these tubes under pressure # this also is an air inflated sorry an air supported structure # which was erected at the University of Nottingham # last Monday # by # # an artist who works solely with inflated # s air supported structures # and it will be going on tour # in Germany # as a promotional # exhibit for # # a tour company holiday tour company # it's # over a thousand square metres of structure and # air supported made out of # coloured # P-V-C fabric and # the cutting patterns here w earlier was talking about cutting patterns were actually just derived by eye and by using books on welding practice how to cut tubes to join them together so no computer programs were used in this at all purely guesswork and # simple geometry mathematics # and as a result of that you can see there are actually wrinkles in the structure in certain places and one thing about # inflated structures under pressure the # there is a relationship between the pressure in the structure and the radius of the curvature and the tensile # stress in the surface and # generally the tighter the radius # to maintain the same tension in the surface you # actually need more pressure so where there is actually a tighter radius here you can see it's not quite so inflated as the rest of the structure here where the cutting pattern has been derived quite well and there is a bigger radius of curvature the the structure is actually quite well # inflated # just to show you how little you need to # support a structure of this size # about six of these # fans were were installed to blow air warm air in fact this was actually heating the air # as it was a very cold day last Monday #
